price-parser.name: price-parser
price-parser.description: Extract price and currency from a raw string

repo.name: price-parser
repo.description: Extract price amount and currency symbol from a raw text string

readme.summary: Excellent documentation with crystal-clear purpose, comprehensive examples, and practical usage patterns for price parsing from web pages.
readme.top_issue: No troubleshooting section for common issues like ambiguous separators or conflicting currency symbols

common_complaints: Decimal parsing inconsistencies (trailing zeros, thousands separators misinterpreted)
Negative number handling not supported
Currency detection failures (non-Latin scripts, subscription terms)
Incorrect amount extraction when text contains multiple numbers
Limited international/non-Latin currency support
sentiment.summary: The project shows signs of abandonment with multiple unresolved critical parsing bugs open since 2020, slow/no maintainer response, and fundamental issues (negative numbers, decimal handling) remaining unfixed despite user reports.

concerns: No commits in past 6 months despite last commit being Oct 2025
26 open issues with no recent closure activity
No merged PRs in past 6 months
No active contributors in past 6 months
Unknown last release date indicates no versioning activity
maintenance.summary: price-parser appears abandoned with zero maintenance activity over the past 6 months and a substantial backlog of unresolved issues.

project_metrics.description: Extract price amount and currency symbol from a raw text string

cves.summary: SQLAlchemy vulnerable to SQL injection
SQLAlchemy vulnerable to SQL Injection via order_by parameter
SQLAlchemy is vulnerable to SQL Injection via group_by parameter
SQLAlchemy through 1.2.17 and 1.3.x through 1.3.0b2 allows SQL Injection via the order_by parameter.
SQLAlchemy 1.2.17 has SQL Injection when the group_by parameter can be controlled.

Multiple SQL injection vulnerabilities in SQLAlchemy before 0.7.0b4, as used in Keystone, allow remote attackers to execute arbitrary SQL commands via the (1) limit or (2) offset keyword to the select
